40.29.text: discovered that Clarissa is actually high

42.30.text: mistress of St Paul's which is one of the

48.21.text: I thought she'd make a brilliant subject

62.16.text: what she's going to do with the rest of

64.14.text: So Clarissa, let me ask you about

67.62.text: teaching. Did you always want to teach? I

69.57.text: come from a family of teachers so my

72.03.text: mother was a teacher, my father's mother

74.04.text: was a teacher and I suppose it was in my

77.07.text: blood in a way but I really went into

78.96.text: teaching because I love my subject. I

80.61.text: read English at University and I just

82.35.text: loved the novels of Henry James, he was

84.39.text: the subject of my masters as a

86.43.text: dissertation and I just thought I I want

89.37.text: everyone in the world to know about how

90.84.text: wonderful these novels are and that was

92.31.text: really what took me into teaching in the

93.69.text: first place. So tell me, you've obviously

99.75.text: position as a teacher. Tell us what

102.96.text: you've loved most about your teaching

104.73.text: career. I think inevitably it's fantastic

108.60.text: to be with young people, it's so

110.01.text: energising, so rejuvenating. They make me

113.22.text: laugh, they challenge me, I learn

115.23.text: something from my pupils every single

117.12.text: day and I've felt that in all the jobs

119.19.text: that I've had in the teaching profession,

120.96.text: whether as a head or as a young teacher.

124.76.text: So is there any aspect of your current

128.10.text: role as a head teacher that you don't

134.91.text: I suppose everything about it is challenging

136.68.text: in its way. I'm very much a people person

139.92.text: so the parts of the job I really love or

142.05.text: when I'm dealing with my colleagues, or

143.43.text: on I'm dealing with the parents or with the

145.08.text: pupils. I much less enjoy the

149.88.text: demands of legal compliance that are

153.26.text: thrust upon us now which are just so

155.73.text: much more extensive than they used to be. I'm

158.70.text: really interested in the sort of lives

160.80.text: of teenage girls today. So what do you

163.50.text: think is the biggest issue facing those

165.69.text: teenage girls that you have in this

167.16.text: school? Well I think teenagers today are

171.03.text: assailed with so much information and so

174.54.text: much pressure from the internet and from

177.42.text: the kind of media role models that

180.00.text: they're invited to admire, whether those

181.80.text: are in magazines or on the websites that

184.17.text: they look at, and if you look at the

186.15.text: models in the magazines that they tend

189.06.text: to read, those are not bodies that any

191.37.text: normal person would have and I think

193.83.text: it's very easy for that to breed a sense

196.02.text: of inadequacy or low self-esteem in

199.71.text: young women, so we very much try to give confidence, to

204.39.text: encourage the girls to think about

206.76.text: themselves as real people, to think about

214.80.text: be always trying to fit into some

217.08.text: pre-conceived idea of what success should

219.63.text: look like. So what do you think are the

222.42.text: most important values that you as High

224.73.text: Mistress of St Paul's can impart to your

230.34.text: known to be a very high achieving

233.82.text: talented, they're full of promise when

236.37.text: they come here, they have many many

237.99.text: different kinds of ability and I think

242.16.text: pressure that they must succeed in every

244.14.text: area. I suppose one of the things I've

246.57.text: tried to instill in them is the

249.51.text: confidence to fail, the confidence to

251.55.text: know that real people don't get it right

253.98.text: all the time and that even Pauliners,

257.79.text: will make mistakes from time to time. And

259.83.text: I try to do that by sharing my own

261.54.text: mistakes with them and by not setting up

266.15.text: that everything they do will be perfect. I

267.95.text: hope that that has taken some pressure

269.69.text: off them, allowed them to drop their

271.88.text: shoulders a little bit and to relax into

273.98.text: their lives and really enjoy learning

275.39.text: because they are so engaged in their

278.15.text: subjects and they do love academic work

281.24.text: but I want them to enjoy it for its own

282.68.text: sake and not just for the badge

284.96.text: collecting at the end so to speak. And

287.83.text: out of that, these high achieving girls

290.51.text: often have very high achieving parents I

293.21.text: and you've instituted a program for

297.20.text: parents. So why did you do that and what

298.88.text: does that look like? It struck us a few

301.34.text: years ago that being a parent can be

306.31.text: however highly qualified you are nobody

309.59.text: trains you to be a parent so we thought

312.86.text: that would be room for giving parents

314.90.text: the opportunity to meet together in

316.43.text: school to talk about themes that concern

319.70.text: them around the upbringing of their

321.53.text: daughters, so that might be how they can

323.84.text: support their daughters at exam time for

326.18.text: example, how they can help keep their

328.46.text: daughter safe online, how they can help

335.30.text: understand that a bit better and

339.74.text: and share their ideas and we found that

341.72.text: to be very popular and I think it's

344.06.text: another way in which we've tried to make

346.31.text: this community relax a little more with

348.32.text: itself. So you've just announced, after 11

352.97.text: years, that you're stepping aside from

354.53.text: your role. So why have you done that now

356.96.text: and how do you feel about leaving such a

359.72.text: prestigious job? Well I encourage the

363.80.text: girls to have the confidence to take

365.24.text: risks so I felt that I should take my

367.64.text: own advice and and take a risk myself. I

371.15.text: absolutely love this job, I can't imagine

373.24.text: any other full-time immersive role that

376.79.text: could possibly be as fulfilling as this,

379.00.text: but I think the time to leave is when

381.86.text: people are saying "Why not when" and I

385.52.text: feel that the school is in great shape,

387.86.text: it's in a fantastic state to hand over

390.20.text: to somebody else but I also feel for

391.88.text: myself that I may have new capability

398.48.text: a page and start a new chapter in my life while

400.64.text: I still feel young enough and energetic

402.92.text: enough and optimistic enough to make new

405.59.text: things happen. So what kind of plans have

409.13.text: you got for this, what we'll call your

410.87.text: third act of your life? Well my plans are

416.09.text: multiple. I'm hoping to write a book

418.07.text: about my experiences in education both

420.62.text: as a pupil, as a teacher and as as a head.

423.92.text: I also want to go on using expertise

432.89.text: setting up new schools. I have a

435.77.text: particular love of fine art and of

438.68.text: sculpture and making sculpture has been

441.05.text: my hobby. I haven't had enough time to

442.70.text: devote to that so I'd like to do more of

444.62.text: that and I've also very much enjoyed the

451.52.text: the latter part of my career as a Head

453.20.text: and I would love to find a way of

455.33.text: continuing to work on an individual

457.58.text: basis with people developing their own

459.20.text: professional lives and see whether I can

461.33.text: help them and encourage more people to

465.20.text: enjoy their work in teaching as much as

468.08.text: I've done. That sounds like you're going

470.21.text: to be really busy! Lots to do there!

473.69.text: fantastic! And how do you view the process

476.99.text: of getting older? I think it's a cliche

481.79.text: but I think the only way to age is

483.80.text: gracefully and to accept the passing of

486.17.text: time and to enjoy the things that

488.72.text: greater experience gives you. So I'm not

492.50.text: in favor of trying to look younger than

497.39.text: one's always with younger people and

499.46.text: the difference is they stay the same age

501.17.text: and you don't you get you get older so I

503.30.text: went into teaching as a 22 year old when

505.25.text: my pupils were hardly any younger than I

506.87.text: was and and now I'm in a very different

509.57.text: place but I think that you can enjoy

513.29.text: whatever age you are and what I think is

515.96.text: fantastic about modern thinking is that

518.84.text: people don't see age as a barrier in the

521.42.text: way that they did in the past, so I feel

523.55.text: I have lots of life to live and young

525.71.text: enough to enjoy it. And finally what do

529.88.text: you love about makeup and of course

536.03.text: creative side of using makeup. I have a
